images.copyright: Christmas star lanterns, Germany (© artas/Getty Images)
images.title: Twinkle, twinkle, paper stars
images.caption: Christmas star lanterns, Germany
images.desc: As Christmas draws near, star lanterns begin to appear everywhere—twinkling from balconies, shining in shop windows, and lighting up market stalls. Their shimmer cuts through the long winter nights, filling streets and homes with joy, color, and a sense of togetherness. But behind these festive decorations lies a story as captivating as their glow.

og.title: Christmas star lanterns, Germany
og.desc: As Christmas draws near, star lanterns begin to appear everywhere—twinkling from balconies, shining in shop windows, and lighting up market…

images.copyright: Snow-covered landscape at Bormio, Lombardy, Italy (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: High mountains, deep history
images.caption: Bormio, Lombardy, Italy
images.desc: Bormio is a mountain town in northern Italy's Lombardy region, nestled in the Alps near the Stelvio Pass. This location has connected communities across mountain valleys for centuries, shaping how people live and move through the region. Today's image features Bormio's winter landscape, a reflection of its high-altitude setting and enduring bond with the surrounding peaks.

og.title: Bormio, Lombardy, Italy
og.desc: Bormio is a mountain town in northern Italy's Lombardy region, nestled in the Alps near the Stelvio Pass. This location has connected…

images.copyright: Temple of the Sun, Capitol Reef National Park, Utah (© Austin Cronnelly/TANDEM Stills + Motion)
images.title: Layers of time in Utah
images.caption: Celebrating 54 years of Capitol Reef National Park
images.desc: Rock layers formed over millions of years and a massive bend in the Earth's crust give this desert a rare window into geologic history. This is Capitol Reef National Park in Utah, where sandstone cliffs and canyons preserve a striking record of the planet's past. December 18 marks the anniversary of its designation as a national park in 1971. Today's featured image highlights the sandstone monoliths of Cathedral Valley, including the Temple of the Sun, part of this extraordinary, protected landscape.

og.title: Celebrating 54 years of Capitol Reef National Park
og.desc: Rock layers formed over millions of years and a massive bend in the Earth's crust give this desert a rare window into geologic history. This…

images.copyright: Eurasian red squirrel in Northumberland, England (© Michael_Conrad/Getty Images)
images.title: Fur, frost, and feast
images.caption: Eurasian red squirrel in Northumberland, England
images.desc: Who could resist that squishy face? A Eurasian red squirrel perches on a snowy pine branch, paws clutching a pine cone like it's the last snack on Earth. These little acrobats stay busy collecting nuts, seeds, and fungi—feasting on fresh finds in summer and on stored cones through winter.

og.title: Eurasian red squirrel in Northumberland, England
og.desc: Who could resist that squishy face? A Eurasian red squirrel perches on a snowy pine branch, paws clutching a pine cone like it's the last…

images.copyright: Handmade gnomes at a Christmas market (© Veronika Seppanen/Shutterstock)
images.title: Tiny hats, big spirits
images.caption: Handmade gnomes at a Christmas market
images.desc: They've got long beards, red hats, and a knack for stealing a tad bit of Santa's thunder every Christmas. Meet the gnome—known as 'tomte' in Sweden and 'nisse' in Norway—whose traditions vary across regions. Rooted in Scandinavian folklore, these tiny guardians watch over homes and farms, keeping families safe through long, dark winters. But there's a catch: treat them kindly, or they may play tricks. A warm bowl of porridge on Christmas Eve is their favorite reward. Said to bring luck and laughter, they might even befriend your garden gnomes, since they often resemble them.

og.title: Handmade gnomes at a Christmas market
og.desc: They've got long beards, red hats, and a knack for stealing a tad bit of Santa's thunder every Christmas. Meet the gnome—known as 'tomte' in…

images.copyright: Lights on Spiegelgracht canal, Amsterdam, Netherlands (© Amith Nag Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Still waters, bright lights
images.caption: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam, Netherlands
images.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods, control water flow, and connect places. From ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt to medieval Europe, they transformed cities like Venice and Bruges into trade hubs. The Netherlands took this even further—by the 17th century, they were designing waterways that shaped cities such as Amsterdam.

og.title: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam, Netherlands
og.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods…

images.copyright: Tufted titmouse perched on pine boughs, Massachusetts (© Tim Laman/NPL/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The great holiday bird-off
images.caption: Audubon Christmas Bird Count
images.desc: Each December, thousands swap wrapping paper for binoculars and step outside for a different kind of holiday tradition: the Audubon Christmas Bird Count. Instead of hunting for bargains, they hunt for birds—with pencils, rather than pellets. Started in 1900 by ornithologist Frank M. Chapman, the count offered a peaceful alternative to the Christmas 'side hunts,' where people competed to shoot the most animals. Chapman had a better idea: count them instead. Over a century later, that simple shift has grown into the world's longest-running citizen-science project.

og.title: Audubon Christmas Bird Count
og.desc: Each December, thousands swap wrapping paper for binoculars and step outside for a different kind of holiday tradition: the Audubon…

images.copyright: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California (© Ron and Patty Thomas/Getty Images)
images.title: Frozen reflections
images.caption: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California
images.desc: Every masterpiece needs a brushstroke to tie it together. For Yosemite National Park, that stroke is the Merced River—painting reflections of granite cliffs, pine forests, and waterfalls across its canvas. One of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers, this waterway begins high in the Sierra Nevada. It gathers meltwater and winds 145 miles west through Yosemite Valley into California's Central Valley.
